dmTitle.infoName: Airworthiness Limitations and Component Life Management

levelledPara.title: Time Limits and Life Limits
levelledPara.para: This Data Module defines the time-limited and life-limited items requiring mandatory replacement or overhaul under ATA Chapter 05. Compliance with these limits is mandatory for continued airworthiness.

levelledPara.title: Regulatory Framework
levelledPara.para: Time and life limits are established in accordance with:

listItem.para: EASA CS-25 Section 25.1529 - Instructions for Continued Airworthiness
FAA Part 25 Section 25.571 - Damage Tolerance and Fatigue Evaluation
Certification Maintenance Requirements (CMR)
Airworthiness Limitation Items (ALI)

levelledPara.title: Life-Limited Parts (LLP)
levelledPara.para: The following component categories are subject to mandatory life limits:

listItem.para: Turbine disks and blades - 20,000 cycles
Compressor disks - 25,000 cycles
Combustion chamber liners - 15,000 cycles
Rotating shafts - 30,000 cycles
Main landing gear cylinders - 40,000 cycles
Nose landing gear cylinders - 35,000 cycles
Landing gear actuators - 50,000 cycles
Wheels and brakes - per manufacturer specification
Wing main spar - 60,000 flight hours
Wing attachment fittings - 90,000 cycles
Fuselage pressure bulkhead - 75,000 cycles
Engine mounting pylons - 50,000 flight hours

levelledPara.title: Time-Limited Components
levelledPara.para: The following systems have calendar-based or operational time limits:

listItem.para: Emergency oxygen generators - 15 years from manufacture date
Emergency escape slides - 12 years from manufacture date
Fire extinguisher bottles - 12 years from last hydrostatic test
ELT batteries - per manufacturer specification (typically 6 years)
Hydraulic hoses - 8 years from manufacture date
Pneumatic ducting - 12 years from installation
Accumulator bladders - 10 years from installation
Seals and O-rings - per component overhaul intervals

levelledPara.title: Life Management Process
levelledPara.para: Life-limited parts tracking and management includes:

listItem.para: Initial installation record with part number, serial number, and initial cycles/hours
Continuous tracking of accumulated cycles/hours via AAMMPP digital passport
Automated alerts at 75%, 90%, and 95% of life limit
Mandatory removal at life limit with proper documentation
Disposition decision (scrap, repair, return to manufacturer)
Digital passport update and configuration state change

levelledPara.title: Fatigue and Damage Tolerance
levelledPara.para: Structural life limits are based on fatigue and damage tolerance analysis:

listItem.para: Full-scale fatigue testing to validate analytical models
Damage tolerance analysis per AC 25.571-1D
Corrosion prevention and control program (CPCP)
Structural health monitoring (SHM) integration
Non-destructive testing (NDT) schedule and acceptance criteria

levelledPara.title: Digital Passport Integration
levelledPara.para: All life-limited and time-limited items are tracked via AMSDP (Aerospace Material & Software Digital Passports):

listItem.para: Unique component identifier linked to digital passport
Real-time life consumption tracking
Automated alerts and compliance monitoring
Blockchain-anchored audit trail for all transactions
Interoperability with MRO and supply chain systems

levelledPara.title: ESG and Sustainability
levelledPara.para: Life limit management includes environmental considerations:

listItem.para: Circular economy principles for component reuse and remanufacturing
Material recovery and recycling at end of life
Hazardous material tracking and disposal per regulations
Carbon footprint assessment of replacement cycles
Extended producer responsibility compliance

levelledPara.title: Compliance and Audit
levelledPara.para: Time and life limit compliance is subject to:

listItem.para: Continuous airworthiness monitoring by regulatory authorities
Annual internal audits per EASA Part-M requirements
Digital audit trail maintained for entire aircraft lifecycle
Non-compliance reporting and corrective action procedures
